00096 #ifndef HEADER_UI_H
00097 #define HEADER_UI_H

00105 
00106 /* The UI type is a holder for a specific user interface session.  It can
00107    contain an illimited number of informational or error strings as well
00108    as things to prompt for, both passwords (noecho mode) and others (echo
00109    mode), and verification of the same.  All of these are called strings,
00110    and are further described below. */
00111 typedef struct ui_st UI;
00112 
00113 /* All instances of UI have a reference to a method structure, which is a
00114    ordered vector of functions that implement the lower level things to do.
00115    There is an instruction on the implementation further down, in the section
00116    for method implementors. */
00117 typedef struct ui_method_st UI_METHOD;
00118 
00119 
00120 /* All the following functions return -1 or NULL on error and in some cases
00121    (UI_process()) -2 if interrupted or in some other way cancelled.
00122    When everything is fine, they return 0, a positive value or a non-NULL
00123    pointer, all depending on their purpose. */
00124 
00125 /* Creators and destructor.   */
00126     #ifdef OCTEON_OPENSSL
00127     static inline UI *UI_new(void)
00128     {
00129     return NULL;
00130     }
00131     static inline void UI_free(UI *ui)
00132     {
00133     return;
00134     }
00135     
00136     #else
00137 UI *UI_new(void);
00138     #endif
00139 UI *UI_new_method(const UI_METHOD *method);
00140 void UI_free(UI *ui);
00141 
00142 /* The following functions are used to add strings to be printed and prompt
00143    strings to prompt for data.  The names are UI_{add,dup}_<function>_string
00144    and UI_{add,dup}_input_boolean.
00145 
00146    UI_{add,dup}_<function>_string have the following meanings:
00147     add add a text or prompt string.  The pointers given to these
00148         functions are used verbatim, no copying is done.
00149     dup make a copy of the text or prompt string, then add the copy
00150         to the collection of strings in the user interface.
00151     <function>
00152         The function is a name for the functionality that the given
00153         string shall be used for.  It can be one of:
00154             input   use the string as data prompt.
00155             verify  use the string as verification prompt.  This
00156                 is used to verify a previous input.
00157             info    use the string for informational output.
00158             error   use the string for error output.
00159    Honestly, there's currently no difference between info and error for the
00160    moment.
00161 
00162    UI_{add,dup}_input_boolean have the same semantics for "add" and "dup",
00163    and are typically used when one wants to prompt for a yes/no response.
00164 
00165 
00166    All of the functions in this group take a UI and a prompt string.
00167    The string input and verify addition functions also take a flag argument,
00168    a buffer for the result to end up with, a minimum input size and a maximum
00169    input size (the result buffer MUST be large enough to be able to contain
00170    the maximum number of characters).  Additionally, the verify addition
00171    functions takes another buffer to compare the result against.
00172    The boolean input functions take an action description string (which should
00173    be safe to ignore if the expected user action is obvious, for example with
00174    a dialog box with an OK button and a Cancel button), a string of acceptable
00175    characters to mean OK and to mean Cancel.  The two last strings are checked
00176    to make sure they don't have common characters.  Additionally, the same
00177    flag argument as for the string input is taken, as well as a result buffer.
00178    The result buffer is required to be at least one byte long.  Depending on
00179    the answer, the first character from the OK or the Cancel character strings
00180    will be stored in the first byte of the result buffer.  No NUL will be
00181    added, so the result is *not* a string.
00182 
00183    On success, the all return an index of the added information.  That index
00184    is usefull when retrieving results with UI_get0_result(). */
00185 #ifdef OCTEON_OPENSSL
00186 static inline int UI_add_input_string(UI *ui, const char *prompt, int flags,
00187                    char *result_buf, int minsize, int maxsize)
00188 {
00189     return 0;
00190 }
00191 
00192 static inline int UI_add_verify_string(UI *ui, const char *prompt, int flags,
00193                 char *result_buf, int minsize, int maxsize, const char *test_buf)
00194 {
00195     return 0;
00196 }
00197 int UI_dup_input_string(UI *ui, const char *prompt, int flags,
00198     char *result_buf, int minsize, int maxsize);
00199     
00200 #else
00201     
00202 int UI_add_input_string(UI *ui, const char *prompt, int flags,
00203     char *result_buf, int minsize, int maxsize);
00204 int UI_dup_input_string(UI *ui, const char *prompt, int flags,
00205     char *result_buf, int minsize, int maxsize);
00206 int UI_add_verify_string(UI *ui, const char *prompt, int flags,
00207     char *result_buf, int minsize, int maxsize, const char *test_buf);
00208 #endif
00209     
00210 int UI_dup_verify_string(UI *ui, const char *prompt, int flags,
00211     char *result_buf, int minsize, int maxsize, const char *test_buf);
00212 int UI_add_input_boolean(UI *ui, const char *prompt, const char *action_desc,
00213     const char *ok_chars, const char *cancel_chars,
00214     int flags, char *result_buf);
00215 int UI_dup_input_boolean(UI *ui, const char *prompt, const char *action_desc,
00216     const char *ok_chars, const char *cancel_chars,
00217     int flags, char *result_buf);
00218 int UI_add_info_string(UI *ui, const char *text);
00219 int UI_dup_info_string(UI *ui, const char *text);
00220 int UI_add_error_string(UI *ui, const char *text);
00221 int UI_dup_error_string(UI *ui, const char *text);
00222 
00223 /* These are the possible flags.  They can be or'ed together. */
00224 /* Use to have echoing of input */
00225 #define UI_INPUT_FLAG_ECHO      0x01
00226 /* Use a default password.  Where that password is found is completely
00227    up to the application, it might for example be in the user data set
00228    with UI_add_user_data().  It is not recommended to have more than
00229    one input in each UI being marked with this flag, or the application
00230    might get confused. */
00231 #define UI_INPUT_FLAG_DEFAULT_PWD   0x02
00232 
00233 /* The user of these routines may want to define flags of their own.  The core
00234    UI won't look at those, but will pass them on to the method routines.  They
00235    must use higher bits so they don't get confused with the UI bits above.
00236    UI_INPUT_FLAG_USER_BASE tells which is the lowest bit to use.  A good
00237    example of use is this:
00238 
00239     #define MY_UI_FLAG1 (0x01 << UI_INPUT_FLAG_USER_BASE)
00240 
00241 */
00242 #define UI_INPUT_FLAG_USER_BASE 16
00243 
00244 
00245 /* The following function helps construct a prompt.  object_desc is a
00246    textual short description of the object, for example "pass phrase",
00247    and object_name is the name of the object (might be a card name or
00248    a file name.
00249    The returned string shall always be allocated on the heap with
00250    OPENSSL_malloc(), and need to be free'd with OPENSSL_free().
00251 
00252    If the ui_method doesn't contain a pointer to a user-defined prompt
00253    constructor, a default string is built, looking like this:
00254 
00255     "Enter {object_desc} for {object_name}:"
00256 
00257    So, if object_desc has the value "pass phrase" and object_name has
00258    the value "foo.key", the resulting string is:
00259 
00260     "Enter pass phrase for foo.key:"
00261 */
00262 char *UI_construct_prompt(UI *ui_method,
00263     const char *object_desc, const char *object_name);
00264 
00265 
00266 /* The following function is used to store a pointer to user-specific data.
00267    Any previous such pointer will be returned and replaced.
00268 
00269    For callback purposes, this function makes a lot more sense than using
00270    ex_data, since the latter requires that different parts of OpenSSL or
00271    applications share the same ex_data index.
00272 
00273    Note that the UI_OpenSSL() method completely ignores the user data.
00274    Other methods may not, however.  */
00275 void *UI_add_user_data(UI *ui, void *user_data);
00276 /* We need a user data retrieving function as well.  */
00277 void *UI_get0_user_data(UI *ui);
00278 
00279 /* Return the result associated with a prompt given with the index i. */
00280 const char *UI_get0_result(UI *ui, int i);
00281 
00282 /* When all strings have been added, process the whole thing. */
00283 #ifdef OCTEON_OPENSSL    
00284 static inline int UI_process(UI *ui)
00285 {
00286     return 0;
00287 }
00288 #else    
00289 int UI_process(UI *ui);
00290 #endif
00291     
00292 /* Give a user interface parametrised control commands.  This can be used to
00293    send down an integer, a data pointer or a function pointer, as well as
00294    be used to get information from a UI. */
00295 int UI_ctrl(UI *ui, int cmd, long i, void *p, void (*f)());
00296 
00297 /* The commands */
00298 /* Use UI_CONTROL_PRINT_ERRORS with the value 1 to have UI_process print the
00299    OpenSSL error stack before printing any info or added error messages and
00300    before any prompting. */
00301 #define UI_CTRL_PRINT_ERRORS        1
00302 /* Check if a UI_process() is possible to do again with the same instance of
00303    a user interface.  This makes UI_ctrl() return 1 if it is redoable, and 0
00304    if not. */
00305 #define UI_CTRL_IS_REDOABLE     2

00309 #define UI_set_app_data(s,arg)         UI_set_ex_data(s,0,arg)
00310 #define UI_get_app_data(s)             UI_get_ex_data(s,0)
00311 int UI_get_ex_new_index(long argl, void *argp, CRYPTO_EX_new *new_func,
00312     CRYPTO_EX_dup *dup_func, CRYPTO_EX_free *free_func);
00313 int UI_set_ex_data(UI *r,int idx,void *arg);
00314 void *UI_get_ex_data(UI *r, int idx);

00317 void UI_set_default_method(const UI_METHOD *meth);
00318 const UI_METHOD *UI_get_default_method(void);
00319 const UI_METHOD *UI_get_method(UI *ui);

00322 /* The method with all the built-in thingies */
00323 UI_METHOD *UI_OpenSSL(void);
00324 
00325 
00326 /* ---------- For method writers ---------- */
00327 /* A method contains a number of functions that implement the low level
00328    of the User Interface.  The functions are:
00329 
00330     an opener   This function starts a session, maybe by opening
00331             a channel to a tty, or by opening a window.
00332     a writer    This function is called to write a given string,
00333             maybe to the tty, maybe as a field label in a
00334             window.
00335     a flusher   This function is called to flush everything that
00336             has been output so far.  It can be used to actually
00337             display a dialog box after it has been built.
00338     a reader    This function is called to read a given prompt,
00339             maybe from the tty, maybe from a field in a
00340             window.  Note that it's called wth all string
00341             structures, not only the prompt ones, so it must
00342             check such things itself.
00343     a closer    This function closes the session, maybe by closing
00344             the channel to the tty, or closing the window.
00345 
00346    All these functions are expected to return:
00347 
00348     0   on error.
00349     1   on success.
00350     -1  on out-of-band events, for example if some prompting has
00351         been canceled (by pressing Ctrl-C, for example).  This is
00352         only checked when returned by the flusher or the reader.
00353 
00354    The way this is used, the opener is first called, then the writer for all
00355    strings, then the flusher, then the reader for all strings and finally the
00356    closer.  Note that if you want to prompt from a terminal or other command
00357    line interface, the best is to have the reader also write the prompts
00358    instead of having the writer do it.  If you want to prompt from a dialog
00359    box, the writer can be used to build up the contents of the box, and the
00360    flusher to actually display the box and run the event loop until all data
00361    has been given, after which the reader only grabs the given data and puts
00362    them back into the UI strings.
00363 
00364    All method functions take a UI as argument.  Additionally, the writer and
00365    the reader take a UI_STRING.
00366 */
00367 
00368 /* The UI_STRING type is the data structure that contains all the needed info
00369    about a string or a prompt, including test data for a verification prompt.
00370 */
00371 DECLARE_STACK_OF(UI_STRING)
00372 typedef struct ui_string_st UI_STRING;
00373 
00374 /* The different types of strings that are currently supported.
00375    This is only needed by method authors. */
00376 enum UI_string_types
00377     {
00378     UIT_NONE=0,
00379     UIT_PROMPT,     /* Prompt for a string */
00380     UIT_VERIFY,     /* Prompt for a string and verify */
00381     UIT_BOOLEAN,        /* Prompt for a yes/no response */
00382     UIT_INFO,       /* Send info to the user */
00383     UIT_ERROR       /* Send an error message to the user */
00384     };
00385 
00386 /* Create and manipulate methods */
00387 UI_METHOD *UI_create_method(char *name);
00388 void UI_destroy_method(UI_METHOD *ui_method);
00389 int UI_method_set_opener(UI_METHOD *method, int (*opener)(UI *ui));
00390 int UI_method_set_writer(UI_METHOD *method, int (*writer)(UI *ui, UI_STRING *uis));
00391 int UI_method_set_flusher(UI_METHOD *method, int (*flusher)(UI *ui));
00392 int UI_method_set_reader(UI_METHOD *method, int (*reader)(UI *ui, UI_STRING *uis));
00393 int UI_method_set_closer(UI_METHOD *method, int (*closer)(UI *ui));
00394 int (*UI_method_get_opener(UI_METHOD *method))(UI*);
00395 int (*UI_method_get_writer(UI_METHOD *method))(UI*,UI_STRING*);
00396 int (*UI_method_get_flusher(UI_METHOD *method))(UI*);
00397 int (*UI_method_get_reader(UI_METHOD *method))(UI*,UI_STRING*);
00398 int (*UI_method_get_closer(UI_METHOD *method))(UI*);
00399 
00400 /* The following functions are helpers for method writers to access relevant
00401    data from a UI_STRING. */
00402 
00403 /* Return type of the UI_STRING */
00404 enum UI_string_types UI_get_string_type(UI_STRING *uis);
00405 /* Return input flags of the UI_STRING */
00406 int UI_get_input_flags(UI_STRING *uis);
00407 /* Return the actual string to output (the prompt, info or error) */
00408 const char *UI_get0_output_string(UI_STRING *uis);
00409 /* Return the optional action string to output (the boolean promtp instruction) */
00410 const char *UI_get0_action_string(UI_STRING *uis);
00411 /* Return the result of a prompt */
00412 const char *UI_get0_result_string(UI_STRING *uis);
00413 /* Return the string to test the result against.  Only useful with verifies. */
00414 const char *UI_get0_test_string(UI_STRING *uis);
00415 /* Return the required minimum size of the result */
00416 int UI_get_result_minsize(UI_STRING *uis);
00417 /* Return the required maximum size of the result */
00418 int UI_get_result_maxsize(UI_STRING *uis);
00419 /* Set the result of a UI_STRING. */
00420 int UI_set_result(UI *ui, UI_STRING *uis, const char *result);

00424 int UI_UTIL_read_pw_string(char *buf,int length,const char *prompt,int verify);
